magaiti wrote:

I vaguely remember there were some tools available, but can't figure it out.

So please tell me how exactly I can get a comprehensive list of existing builds given my class combination.

 
I already linked 2 of the closest builds from here on the ECB.  Without the filter, it is not easy to locate clones in these parts.  You'd need either Excel or OpenOffice to use that.  There is a CSV version for those that prefer to import the data into their own spreadsheet app, but I think OpenOffice will open an .xls file "as is", just not as completely as Excel would.

For that list of legacy builds I found, follow the How and Where to Access Legacy Archives instructions.  Dunno which browser you use, but Firefox and MSIE digests Javascript just fine so you can run the search locally.  I set some critieria myself.  I think I chose Bard 10-40, PM 10-40 and RDD 10-40 to get the list you see.  You may get different results (probably a longer list) if you don't limit the search the way I did.

You do not need to compare EVERY build you find with a similar class split... just those that seem to be very similar in focus to yours (just the class split itself is not a focus, it's what you do with the combo that can make it unique).  Basically, distinguish your contribution from those that have preceded yours and the reason(s) you chose the path you did instead of what they did.

Also, one more tip... type the build's name into your post alongside the class split you posted at the top. When people copy/paste your build to use it for gameplay, it's best that the title goes along with the build itself.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Good build magaiti and i like your "refinements" both here and in your Dwarven Defender for example. The only caveat of this build is that it flourishes quite late, but i know you did that to preserve your AB as much as possible. I think you succeed your target in both the AB and AC department but i have two objections, nothing major-just some areas you could use some improvements, at least in my mind.

a) You have ESF: Discipline in there, but both you and I know, you don't need that. Shuffle your feats and find a way to add Lingering Song to your Bard. This makes him/her a lot more enjoyable to play and offers more staying power to your build.
b) If you are going for a non-dev-crit version, then instead of martial weapons, change to exotics and take a nice bastard sword/scythe to wield, instead of the overused scimy.

Valerfor wrote:

The only caveat of this build is that it flourishes quite late, but i know you did that to preserve your AB as much as possible. I think you succeed your target in both the AB and AC department but i have two objections, nothing major-just some areas you could use some improvements, at least in my mind.

a) You have ESF: Discipline in there, but both you and I know, you don't need that. Shuffle your feats and find a way to add Lingering Song to your Bard. This makes him/her a lot more enjoyable to play and offers more staying power to your build.
b) If you are going for a non-dev-crit version, then instead of martial weapons, change to exotics and take a nice bastard sword/scythe to wield, instead of the overused scimy.
ESF: Discipline usefulness depends on the environment you are playing in. If you don't need it, then for DevCrit build, I recommend swapping Epic Prowess as well, for two Great STR feats.
Scimitar/Rapier are overused, but for a reason. Considering high damage bonus you get in epics from STR and weapon enhancement/damage effects, crit profile increases damage output better than base weapon die.
Scythe is definitely best option if you go two-handed, for the same reason.

If you have acces to armor with no Arcane Spell Failure, the build can be tweaked to use it. For example if you can get Mithral Shirt, and choose to use a two-handed weapon, you won't need Still Spell, nor Heavy Armor Proficiency. Take Lingering Song, Toughness, or KD instead. Or rework DevCrit build to free more epic feats for Great STR.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
magaiti wrote:
Scimitar/Rapier are overused, but for a reason. Considering high damage bonus you get in epics from STR and weapon enhancement/damage effects, crit profile increases damage output better than base weapon die...
...only against weaker, crittable foes.  Vs. opposition with elevated AC, most of the lower rolls on the crit range will miss anyway.  For the toughest bosses, crit range has zero importance since only naturals will hit them.  High intrinsic damage ALWAYS has a positive effect especially in STR builds.  The reason wide crit range impresses players is because they can wade into a mob of goblins or bandits and create ultimate havoc like a killing machine.  Surrounded by shadows in the crypt?  Not so useful and probably more of a liability with lower base damage.
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
Anyway... a rather long evaluation for your build to digest follows...

Bearing in mind that there are different focus in most of the legacy builds, there is some value in publishing a semi-clone like yours where it can be accessed more easily right here on the ECB.  But let's evaluate the closest ones briefly, assuming that the class split is an optimization by itself...

Ithacan's Undead Dragon Skald: very similar, but DevCrit w/o Blind Fight and pre-v1.69 (EMA taken illegally); low HP; commits to taunt but will do poor vs. opposed taunts; skill set not fully optimized though does contain detection skill

Ithacan's Undead Dragon Skald with Elf Ears (v. 3): also similar but suffering from the same shortcomings of the human version, but even worse skills and a perform level only good for song 8; this is not a taunter either; this one seems to comply with v1.69 so that's a step in the right direction

Wildeyes' Revised Avatar of Ruin: very hard to assess this build but it's a halfling so would need to go 2H with scimi; it's DevCrit and lacks essentials like Blind Fight;  it's not a DEX build so is not able to take advantage of most of the race bonuses; this is not a taunter either

Herbie Shimmer's Bard 14/RDD 10/PM 16: build not optimized and splits increases between STR and DEX; a good one to ignore regarding this split

Zhoreb's Grim Bard: finally figured out this was another elven version, the build is very hard to follow; starting split is not optimized (no benefit from DEX 12 with a Cat buff available); a real odd feat sequence with Curse song and Heavy armor in epic;  this was DevCrit so suffers from the same disease as other feat-starved versions;  must have been built for a server with plenty of gear enhancements to compensate for the poor build choices

Grimnir77's Black Widow: a DEXer; seems an odd choice to me without any feat to protect the loss of DEX AC;  at least it can fight well against concealment, though;  definitely the opposite direction from most

Wi11oW's Singing Kukri's: gotta admit... extremely unusual with a DevCrit dual-wield kukris;  problem is without being able to taunt and even with bard song (no curse song either), the DW AB just won't cut it.  All-in-all not a dominating combat presence but very unique.

I realize I grabbed a few more builds than necessary but by sampling others, the trend is easier to uncover, at least for me.  One thing I can't figure is the trending focus in rapier.  Makes no sense to neutralize the effect of Keen Edge with a weapon type that won't qualify.  I suspect most builds were intended to be played where the Keen property appears on all melee weapons including clubs.  But that's assuming a lot IMO.
 
Now for my own reshuffle of the lead build.  Understand, I don't build RDD myself because of where I play most of the time, in environments that have rebalanced the exploitation classes in order to encourage diverse builds among its community of players, but for those who can implement them as per their default...

Analysis

IMO STR 38 is too costly a goal to set.  For +1AB/+1dmg, the toon loses 1 DEX AC and a much more powerful skill set including boosting saves vs. spells.  Pedestrian saves are a weakness of this build and need all the help at hand.

This MUST be a taunter.  Period.  Else, it certainly won't be optimized for most environments.  The Expertise/Taunt combo could raise your active mundane AC to at least 76 when fully buffed so consider that feat.  Besides raising the attack potential, taunting provides a means to deal with high-level casters.   

The contradiction of the feat selection Still Spell without any Concentration deserves questioning.  Offensive casting for a Bard 14 is mediocre at best with poor DCs and penetration so ends up more of a convenience than an actual offensive threat.  However if considered important nevertheless, loses its viability without securing the casting action itself.  Besides the vulnerability to casting interruption, there are opposed taunts to consider.  Still Spell and maxed Concentration are joined at the hip (no pun intended).

The key focus of this build is the two songs.  That's where the real strength lies. Caster level 14 spell buffs (other than epic ones) are easily dispelled and should not be depended on (PM levels add only duration, not indispellability or caster level).  But the songs are relatively stable so Lingering Song makes some sense.

Also, keep in mind that Extended buffs must be cast without armor/shield equipped or fail miserably with hvy armor/tower.  If you are not assured getting access to all the standard pots, even Scribe Scroll/Craft Wand makes a lot of sense since item casting cannot be interrupted.  

The most glaring weakness of this build (IMO) is the lack of a detection skill, probably Listen.  I'd have no problem reducing UMD down to a level to use divine scrolls/wands (10-15 points should be plenty) and slide the rest into Listen.  Combined with a constant buff of Amplify, it will help avoid wading into a mass of stealthers... melee, ranged or caster types.  See Invisibility will not spot GS-users, but Listen will, the moment they start to move or cast a spell.

Note the slight rejuggling I made in the pre-epic levels to get regular Tumble and UMD dumps and the priority to heavy armor, all for better early playability.  Actually, until Bard 10 and ext haste, there is little need to extend buffs so it can be delayed.  I suppose a case could be made for ext Darkness's usefulness so shortly after bard 7 works. Most important is an early AB bonus (WF) and Curse Song.

Obviously, you are concerned about getting KD'd or disarmed, else you would not be as neurotic about discipline levels.  I can't justify the investment in Epic Discipline, though.  You'll be getting a +2 boost from a cast of Bull and another +2 from song 11.   With as high an AC rating as you can reach, I doubt seriously that the penalties from the opposed special attacks will provide many opportunities to hit your toon.  Improved Disarm spam exploit is about the only exception so keep a spare weapon handy on your gear swap.

Use whatever scraps of information or suggestions contained here.  I have no intent of professing ownership, just passing on items for your consideration.  I'd recommend retaining your build, but with better optimizations and, of course, a skill schedule to match the level-up guide.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Didn't think you could increase skill level even higher, but right there it is!  Good work!   Better and clearer than any of the legacy versions, IMO.

^^^,,, what Valerfor just said.^^^  I'd prefer spreading out bard dumps in pre-epic a bit more, for better playability.  Waiting 15 levels for tumble/taunt/discipline dumps seems a l-o-o-o-n-g time to me.

One point about how UMD works with bard... all the UMD ranks required to use all level scrolls, arcane or divine, is the value of scroll (or item) itself.  Typically, 10 ranks is plenty (UMD 10 is good for values up to 20K gold, UMD 15 is good for values up to 100K gold).  The "value" is not necessarily the cost in a store because those almost always reflect a mark-up of the true value (UMD check only keeps track of the value in the server 2DA rather than the cost in a store which can vary wildly).

Bard UMD in excess of 10 would be just to equip class-specific gear or expensive divine wands/rods you anticipate to be available.  Bard's UMD automatically skips the hardcore scroll check so those odd numbers have no benefit.  UMD 27 (30) resolves the same as UMD 30 (33).  Dunno where I'd recommend sliding spare points, though.  Everything is covered!

If you check the build spoiler in post #7, I believe I've chosen a viable class-feat sequence for the bard dumps.  Use it as a reference for your own preferences. Your new ability spread will be different with better skill distribution (and I made a typo on the Still feat calling it "Silent" *doh!*), but otherwise tried to stay as close to your original template as possible.  All the similar builds using this class split mature late but that is the nature of the combo and no getting around it without nerfing your combat stats significantly.
